author: 0xraino
content: +1 on the security recommendation of doing this only with 4444

author: 0xraino
content:
> rollups are unlikely to dominate Ethereum block space in the short term future
While this gives me peace on the state growth side, doesn't give much peace on the p2p side, which as far as I know (and I probably don't know something important), isn't going to level up its throughput anytime soon.

In fact, rollups tending to use ~100% of block space in the medium term probably means making the max block size even lower than it is today, no? In my model, great rollup adoption means we hit that 1 MB limit every block.

author: ansgar.eth
content: Importantly though, 4444 would not yet have to be implemented, just agreed upon, by the time the calldata cost reduction would reach mainnet

author: ansgar.eth
content: But the EIP would lower the max block size, so peak networking strain should go down, no?

author: 0xraino
content: Yes but lower it to ~1MB, still higher than the ~500kb that caused issues

author: 0xraino
content: So not really an issue with this specifically

author: ansgar.eth
content: But any attacker can today create 2MB blocks

author: ansgar.eth
content: Presumably we think the network can handle those?

author: 0xraino
content:
I don't have strong knowledge about what the network can handle in terms of block size, just going off the number quoted here.

Any attacker can today but rollups can fill that space profitably

author: 0xraino
content: It will be the norm

author: ansgar.eth
content: Also this should become much less of an issue with PoS, where min block time goes up to 12s

author: ansgar.eth
content: Right, I am just saying, for peak stress (bandwidth, computation, â€¦) the relevant metric should be the worst case. Whereas for state / history growth it should be the average case

author: 0xraino
content: I guess what I'm saying is that the peak and average block size tend to the same thing over time because of the usage pattern of rollups

author: ansgar.eth
content: Yes, and what Iâ€˜m saying is: We already have to be robust against the worst case, so we might as well have the worst case every single block. ðŸ™‚

author: 0xraino
content: Yeah, totally agreed. It just doesn't make sense to me why the worst case is set to where it is in the doc given vitalik quotes ~500kb as problematic

author: djrtwo
content:
fwiw, we *must* to bound node storage regardless of a calldata gas reduction. Even without this EIP, rollups might end up dominating the L1 gas markets. I suspect something like this would accelerate it though.

I'm not sure that we must implement or even pick 4444 prior to a calldata price reduction. I think instead we must commit to solve the problem in the medium term and have a few very viable paths to do so

author: djrtwo
content: I see 4444 or something similar as critical to the sustainability of the chain in the long run. Not an if imo, more of a how and when.

author: phabc
content: How and when are the two best EIP killer questions ðŸ˜„

author: pietjepuk
content: With people generally not happy if the cost of an operation is unexpectedly increased (or reverted to its old value), one thing to possibly add to the calldata EIP is something along the lines of "This lowering of calldata is likely to be temporary, e.g. will be reverted to its previous value of 16 when sharding is introduced". Maybe Micah disagrees with such a statement being part of an EIP, but at least that leaves the door open to make it more expensive again in the future. Also leave the door open to just leaving it as-is when sharding is introduced of course.
